conversation.content: Did you see that email about the new parking policy?
Yeah, I saw it and [empathetically] I know it's hitting everyone pretty hard. They're basically cutting our spots in half while doubling the monthly fee.
It's [joking] almost like they want us to quit.
Well, you know, the timing is, uhh, suspicious considering they just, I mean, announced record profits last quarter.
So, are people, like, actually going to, um, do anything about it or, basically, just complain?
People will complain for, hmm, about two weeks then, [condescending], accept it because, you know, that's what always happens here. Nobody actually pushes back on anything substantial.
That's depressing.
It is depressing but it's also predictable corporate behavior. They test how much they can take away before people actually revolt.
I guess, the thing is, we could, er, organize something, honestly, if people cared enough.
We could try but [frustrated] I've attempted organizing pushback three times before. People sign petitions then chicken out when management starts asking questions.
Three times? What happened?
First was healthcare cuts, umm, second was, [relieved], mandatory unpaid overtime, and, actually, third was when they eliminated remote work. Each time people folded within days.
But, like, this feels different, you know, because parking affects, uhh, literally everyone.
It affects everyone which, anyway, means everyone has, sort of, something to lose if they, well, stick their neck out. That's exactly why nothing will change.
Okay so, we just, err, accept it and, basically, move on like, hmm, always?
Or we document everything and file a formal complaint with the labor board. They can't retaliate against a legitimate legal filing.
Would that, actually, even work though, I mean, or would they, uhh, just find other ways to, honestly, make our lives miserable?
They'd probably make things uncomfortable but at least we'd have legal protection. Better than rolling over again.
You're [very slowly] right, we should at least try something.
Tomorrow at lunch let's draft that complaint together. If we're going down, might as well go down swinging instead of whimpering.
